text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Mining &
Minerals Daily Daily \-- Researchers detail new data in Metals Research \-
Metallurgy. According to news reporting from Warsaw, Poland, by NewsRx
journalists, research stated, "The present research is focused on the
characterization of the composites from Al2O3-Cu-Ni system. Two methods of
ceramic-metal composite forming were applied: uniaxial powder pressing and
Pulse Plasma Sintering (PPS)."

Funders for this research include National Science Centre, Foundation for
Polish Science (FNP) - START 2019 scholarship.

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the Warsaw
University of Technology, "To obtain the samples the powder mixtures
containing 85 vol.% of Al(2)O(3 )and 15 vol.% of metal powders were used.
Influence of the sintering process on microstructure and mechanical properties
of the two series of the composites was analyzed in detail. The selected
physical properties of samples were characterized by Archimedes immersion
method. Vickers hardness and the fracture toughness of the composites was
determined as well. The microstructure of the composites was characterized by
XRD, SEM, EDX. Fracto-graphy investigation was carried out as well.
Independently on composite production method Al2O3, Cu, Ni, and CuNi phases
were revealed. Fractography investigation results revealed different character
of fracture in dependence of fabrication method."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Pulse Plasma
Sintered samples were characterized by higher crack resistance and higher
Vickers hardness in comparison to the specimens manufactured by uniaxial
pressing."

For more information on this research see: Effect of the Powder Consolidation
Method Type On the Microstructure and Selected Properties of Al2o3-cu-ni
Composites. _Archives of Metallurgy and Materials_ , 2020;65(2):967-974.
_Archives of Metallurgy and Materials_ can be contacted at: Polska Akad Nauk,
Polish Acad Sciences, Inst Metall & Mater Sci Pas, Pl, 00-901 Warszawa,
Poland.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting J. Zygmuntowicz, Warsaw University of Technology, Faculty of
Materials Science and Engineering, 141 Woloska Str, Pl-02507 Warsaw, Poland.
Additional authors for this research include P. Piotrkiewicz, W. Kaszuwara and
M. Wachowski.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.24425/amm.2020.132845>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Report Summarizes Metallurgy Study Findings from Warsaw University of Technology (Effect of the Powder Consolidation Method Type On the Microstructure and Selected Properties of Al2o3-cu-ni Composites): Metals Research - Metallurgy
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Mining & Minerals Daily Daily -- Researchers detail new data in Metals Research - Metallurgy. According to news reporting from Warsaw, Poland, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “The present research is focused on the characterization of the composites from Al2O3-Cu-Ni system. Two methods of ceramic-metal composite forming were applied: uniaxial powder pressing and Pulse Plasma Sintering (PPS).”

Funders for this research include National Science Centre, Foundation for Polish Science (FNP) - START 2019 scholarship.

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the Warsaw University of Technology, “To obtain the samples the powder mixtures containing 85 vol.% of Al(2)O(3 )and 15 vol.% of metal powders were used. Influence of the sintering process on microstructure and mechanical properties of the two series of the composites was analyzed in detail. The selected physical properties of samples were characterized by Archimedes immersion method. Vickers hardness and the fracture toughness of the composites was determined as well. The microstructure of the composites was characterized by XRD, SEM, EDX. Fracto-graphy investigation was carried out as well. Independently on composite production method Al2O3, Cu, Ni, and CuNi phases were revealed. Fractography investigation results revealed different character of fracture in dependence of fabrication method.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “Pulse Plasma Sintered samples were characterized by higher crack resistance and higher Vickers hardness in comparison to the specimens manufactured by uniaxial pressing.”

For more information on this research see: Effect of the Powder Consolidation Method Type On the Microstructure and Selected Properties of Al2o3-cu-ni Composites. Archives of Metallurgy and Materials, 2020;65(2):967-974. Archives of Metallurgy and Materials can be contacted at: Polska Akad Nauk, Polish Acad Sciences, Inst Metall & Mater Sci Pas, Pl, 00-901 Warszawa, Poland.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting J. Zygmuntowicz, Warsaw University of Technology, Faculty of Materials Science and Engineering, 141 Woloska Str, Pl-02507 Warsaw, Poland. Additional authors for this research include P. Piotrkiewicz, W. Kaszuwara and M. Wachowski.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.24425/amm.2020.132845. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
